https://www.ft.com...-bc52-0c7211ef3198

11:14 am
PM

BE

Well, yes. It can't pay a dividend so soon after having serious questions raised about its balance sheet stability. It's not Glencore.

BE

Here's Barclays to summarise where we are.

11:15 am
BE

Over the last two years the key variable in estimating Tesco’s value has been the
margin outlook, particularly in the UK. Tesco’s limited guidance and very mixed
profit delivery has left an extremely wide range of sell-side estimates – the highest
18/19 UK EBIT forecast is greater than 2.4x that of the lowest (source: VUMA). We expect
sentiment to change significantly now Tesco has outlined its margin ambitions (3.5-
4.0% group margin for 19/20E) – especially considering that its 1H performance
already shows very strong momentum (UK EBIT was 28% higher than BBG
consensus). Admittedly, the margin expansion is expected to be weighted towards
later years and – given a still competitive UK market – it may not be fully factored
into the share price immediately. The net pension deficit of £5.9bn is also at the top
end of expectations. Nevertheless, the clear beat on 1H profit and the very welcome
guidance means we expect the share price to build on its already strong
performance (up c18% since mid-September). We raise our price target to 235p.

BE

1H performance strong in almost all respects: 2Q UK LFL sales were +0.9%, stronger
than 1Q (+0.3%) and ahead of consensus (+0.5% - source: BBG). UK EBIT of £389m
was 28% ahead of BBG consensus – this implies a 1H margin of 1.81%, up by 23bps
from 2H despite the investment in Farm Brands. Tesco Bank and International were
collectively marginally below consensus but group EBIT was 14% ahead. The net
pension deficit rose from £2.6bn to £5.9bn across 1H – driven by the real discount rate
falling by 160bps (more than the c100bps we had expected).

BE

Implications of the margin guidance: Applying the mid-point of Tesco’s guidance to a
19/20 sales number of £58bn implies an EBIT of £2.175bn. Deducting £300m of
interest and applying a tax rate of 23% implies an EPS of 17.5p. Conversely, a more
optimistic scenario (4.0% margin and 21% tax) gives 19.3p of EPS and a more cautious
scenario (3.5% margin and 25% tax) gives 15.7p of EPS. The central scenario implies a
PE of c11x, the optimistic scenario c10x and the cautious scenario 12.0x (at 189p).

11:15 am
BE

Changes to forecasts and price targets: We only formally forecast out to 18/19, but
today’s statement brings changes to nearer-term forecasts. We do not materially
change 16/17 EBIT forecasts (we are already in line with Tesco’s planned £1.2bn). We
do move up our EBIT and EPS forecasts for 18/19E by c9-10% given the company’s
confidence that significant self-help opportunities will materially boost margin.

BE

And Morgan Stanley.

BE

Bottom line: As expected, this was a robust operational performance from Tesco
at its interims with Group EBIT coming in 14% above consensus expectations,
driven by higher than expected profitability in the UK, which expanded
sequentially (while Tesco had guided for a decline back in April).
For the first time, Tesco provided today longer term EBIT guidance and indicated
that it is expecting Group EBIT margin to come in between 3.5% and 4% in FY20.
There is no gathered consensus expectation for FY20, but we suspect that
consensus currently stands at ~3.2% (FY19 is 2.8%). So this should lead to
consensus earnings upgrades and be taken well by the market.
That being said, on the negative, we would point out that Tesco is indicating that
it expects an FY17 Group EBIT of £1.2bn, which is in line with current consensus
expectations (£1,183m) and indicates that cost cutting benefits will be back end
loaded (i.e. Tesco is implicitly endorsing FY18 consensus of £1.4bn) and it is raising
its three year average capex plan to £1.4bn (vs. ~£1,250m expected by
consensus). Also, we would point out that Tesco figures released today (pension
deficit increasing to £5.9bn, capex, FY20 EBIT margin of 3.5% to 4.0%, etc.) are
very much in line with Morgan Stanley’s current expectations (e.g. we have an
EBIT margin of 3.8% in FY20e).

11:17 am
BE

Worth noting, since it was on the right, that the pension number's big but not a particularly significant to your immediate outlook.

BE

Pensions: IAS 19 pension deficit increased by ~£3.2bn on a post deferred tax
basis, from £2.6bn as of Feb. 2016 to £5.9bn today. On a pre-tax basis, the
pension deficit moved by £3.9bn, from £3.2bn to £7.1bn. Of note, it is the triennial
(not the IFRS) pension deficit valuation that drives the annual cash payments
into the scheme (£270m p.a. currently), and the next update is only due in 2018
(based on March 2017 data).

BE

Sector responding as you'd expect.

11:20 am
BE

Today's interims appear to confirm the potential for Tesco's UK margin
recovery to accelerate over the balance of 16/17 and beyond. A new 19/20 group EBIT
margin ambition of 3.5% to 4% (JEFe 3.1%) looks underpinned by a new £1.5bn savings
plan. Still, Tesco remains very leveraged (we now estimate lease adj net debt/EBITDAR of greater than 5x for 16/17). Current valuation (cal 2017 PE of 22x and 7.6x EV/EBITDA) reflects the potential for domestic profit recovery, but further upside (beyond today's likely strong move) requires a more +ve inflection in industry dynamics.

So today we get a weirdly structured non-cash offer at a NAV discount that is not convincingly better than Harvourvest's offer

PM

SVG Capital PLC (SVI:LSE): Last: 653.00, down 21 (-3.12%), High: 664.50, Low: 650.00, Volume: 545.50k
11:26 am
BE

And a lot of justification about why it's the right thing to do to sell SVG at sub NAV, which is the opposite its management was arguing some days ago.

BE

It's a bit of a shambles really.

BE

Winterfloods' Simon Elliott is the go-to analyst for investment trusts. Here's his take.

11:26 am
BE

Shareholders in SVG Capital have a difficult decision to make. The Board and management of SVG Capital have been consistent from the outset that HarbourVest’s 650p cash bid undervalued the fund. This was reinforced by the publication of its interim results which showed that, adjusting for cash, the bid valued the investment portfolio on a mid-teen discount. This felt opportunistic and it was no surprise to us that the formal level of acceptances appear to stall around 27%, essentially Coller Capital, despite a further 15% of shareholders signing letters of intent to support HarbourVest’s offer. While some might describe such practice as ‘leaning on the bid’ it made sense to us that shareholders sat tight and waited to see if further bids were forthcoming.

BE

There may be some disappointment this morning that a full cash bid higher than 650p is not on the table. Instead SVG Capital has entered into a provisional agreement with Pomona and Pantheon Ventures to sell 50% of the investment portfolio on a 7.8% discount on a constant currency basis. This will be accompanied by a £450m tender at 700p in December and a further £300m tender at NAV early in 2017. The remaining portfolio is expected to be sold in the first half of next year with the wind down to be completed by the end of 2017. Estimated costs of the defence, tenders and wind down are £33m, equivalent to 21p per share.

In our opinion shareholders have three options: accept HarbourVest’s 650p before its first close on 6 October (tomorrow), after which time the firm could withdraw its offer if less than 50% of shares have accepted; sell through the secondary market if the price is above 650p; or look to participate in the forthcoming tenders as the SVG Capital management team seeks to maximise shareholder value. In order for the final option to be attractive, shareholders will have to be confident that there is a reasonable uplift to the 650p bid.

BE

We estimate that the fund’s NAV would be around 715p on a pro-forma basis assuming the sale and managed wind down go ahead. This is adjusted for the dilution to the NAV following the sale at a discount and the 21p of estimated costs but a 3.5% positive currency move since 31 July. We calculate that 480p per share will effectively be returned to shareholders through the two tender offers (288p and 192p), leaving further potential proceeds of 235p (compared with a guaranteed 170p under the HarbourVest 650p bid). These are clearly subject to a number of factors including foreign exchange movements, underlying performance and discounts on any further sales. Given the execution risk, we believe that smaller shareholders may be tempted to seek an exit through the secondary market. For larger shareholders the choice is more difficult particularly as there is no guarantee that HarbourVest’s offer will remain on the table after tomorrow.

11:27 am
PM

ok, that's helpful

PM

But I think i might go back to trying to ignore this one

BE

And Stifel, which has noted previously how quickly SVG's burning through cash while this pantomime progresses.

11:28 am
BE

We suspected a change in approach from the SVG board when
last week’s defence document talked about an “alternative transaction” rather
than “an offer” as previously mentioned. A full cash offer for the company at a
significantly higher level, i.e. 700p, always looked difficult to achieve. This
reflects the complexity of valuing private equity portfolios and the short
timescale to find a ‘white knight’. Instead the board has decided to go down
the route of an asset sale and break-up, with periodic returns of cash.
However, there are question marks over the valuation of portfolio disposals
after the initial one and also potential market valuation risks, given the orderly
wind-down of the company is expected to take around 15 months.

BE

The costs of the tender offers, defence proposals and wind-down of
SVG are an eye-watering £33m or 21p per share. The initial sale of assets at
£379m vs. a valuation of £401m at 31/07/16 also reduces NAV by £22m or
14p per share. Taking the NAV of 735p at 31/07/16, the adjusted NAV for
portfolio sale writedown and all costs reduces NAV by 35p to 700p. Although it
should be noted that the tender costs are likely to be spread across a number
of future tenders.

BE

Value of the SVG break-up? We have made an initial ‘first-read’ calculation
on the value of the break-up. This takes into account the 735p NAV at
31/07/16, tender costs, wind-down costs and loss on the sale of the initial
portfolio. We also assume the remaining investment portfolio is sold at a
discount of 10% to 31/07/16 valuation which is similar to the 7.8% discount in
the initial portfolio sale. In what we hope would be a ‘worst-case’ scenario our
calculation is a figure of around 675p per share. If instead we assume that
after the initial portfolio sale on a discount, the remaining portfolio is sold at the
31/07/16 valuation, the break-up is worth around 700p over 15 months which
is well above the HarbourVest offer. Indeed, if the portfolio can be sold in
excess of the July valuation (less costs), a more optimistic scenario gives an
outcome in excess of 700p per share.

Land Securities Group PLC (LAND:LSE): Last: 1,029, down 25 (-2.37%), High: 1,055, Low: 1,028, Volume: 596.24k
Intu Properties PLC (INTU:LSE): Last: 294.10, down 6.7 (-2.23%), High: 300.80, Low: 293.50, Volume: 971.87k
British Land Company PLC (BLND:LSE): Last: 616.33, down 12.17 (-1.94%), High: 630.50, Low: 615.32, Volume: 1.15m
11:33 am
BE

SocGen -- a French bank, unless I'm mistaken -- thinks Brexit might not be terribly good long-term for property values.

BE

Or "Brexit will be a long and painful process that will damage the UK economy and inevitably hurt the sector," is how they phrase it.

BE

The PM dismissed outright a free-movement-of-people deal as a way of
keeping single market access. As a result, some companies will have to relocate parts of their business to retain access to the EU single market. Extrapolating data from previous cycles, we expect 50k job losses in London. Take-up has already been falling by 37% in 2Q according to JLL, and by 48% in August according to CBRE, and is now largely below the 10-year average. Since 23 June, many businesses in London are reconsidering their need to move, according to LAND. This may push vacancy to 9% by end 2017e.

11:35 am
BE

The balance has switched in favour of the tenant. Rent-free periods are on
the rise (by two to six months, according to LAND) and while headline rents are holding well so far, net effective rent is falling. All landlords are now on the rush to let vacant space ahead of next year’s significant rise in supply. Speculative supply currently under construction represents 4.3% (or 9.6m sqft) of the overall London market (vs. 3.0% on average over 10 years) and an increasing supply of second-hand space (grey vacancy) is to weigh further on rental value. We anticipate rents to fall by 24% in the event of a ‘hard Brexit’.

BE

Following the post-financial-crisis polarisation between prime and non-prime assets, we believe property assets will see some sub-polarisation. This should result in a further division of assets into: those with long-term leases that should prevent yield from expanding and capital values from falling and those with short leases that should suffer from yield expansion and price decline. In London, the longest WAULT is BLND with 9.8 years followed by LAND 9.2 years, then DLN with 8.1 years and GPOR with 7.5 years, all including pre-lets.

BE

Short-term positives: While we expect the upcoming reported NAV in November to fall
following the 4-5% price decline registered in July and August, it appears that the benefit of
long leases may prevent this from happening. When combined with a likely supportive Autumn Statement (to be presented on 23 November) to ‘reset’ Britain’s fiscal policy, we may see these positives eventually create a more positive sentiment towards UK REITs. Share prices may temporally react positively, in our view.

11:36 am
BE

Vicious yield effect: We stick to our cautious stance on UK REITs, and maintain our capital
value decline of 25% peak-to-trough. Interestingly, the 4.0% yield for London in 2Q is an
equivalent – i.e. based on market rent and discounting future rental growth – which on global standards translates into an initial yield below 3.0%. Consequently, yield should expand mechanically (and price decline) on lower and then negative rental value growth expectations.

The Chinese city (and rapidly-expanding
technology hub) of Shenzhen continues to
lead the rankings, although its annual rate
of growth has slowed significantly from 63%
last quarter to 47%.
Due in part to Shenzhen’s slower rate of
growth, the gap between the strongest
and weakest performing city housing market
has shrunk from 74 percentage points in
March 2016 to 59 points in June.
Six Chinese cities (Shenzhen, Shanghai,
Nanjing, Beijing, Guangzhou and Hangzhou)
all sit within the top ten rankings for annual
price growth. Their ascension has been rapid.
According to data from China’s National
Bureau of Statistics the average annual rate
of growth for the top ten performing Chinese
cities equates to 22% in the year to June, a
year earlier the comparable figure was -1.1%
for the same ten cities (figure 3).

a direct impact on housing demand

11:44 am
PM

Keeping White British Working People Warm

BE

On a more fundamental tack we have RBC calling the top of the sector.

BE

Downgrading SVT and UU to Underperform on valuation

11:45 am
BE

What has changed?
• We look in-depth into each of the water companies' return on regulated equity (RORE) for this
regulatory period (2015-2020 or AMP6). Through our estimates, we are able to estimate the implied
outperformance from totex and financing that contribute to RORE, while holding rewards/penalties
from SIM (customer service) and ODIs (delivery of promised outcomes) relatively neutral.
• In valuing the companies, we now ascribe specific values to each of the companies' water business
segments. These include wholesale water and wastewater (i.e. the RAB businesses), household retail,
non-household retail and other appointed/non-appointed businesses.
• In discounting the economic outperformance of the companies, we have also now extended the
model beyond FY20 and take an initial view of RORE/ROA achievable within AMP (i.e. importantly, we
have lowered the real risk-free rate and real cost of debt by 25bps each).

BE

So ............

BE

Report highlights:
• RORE - Ofwat's definition of RORE is open to interpretation and we generally found two different approaches to calculating financing outperformance. In our interpretation (better aligned to UU's approach), we see PNN, SVT and UU achieving average AMP6 ROREs of 9.6%, 7.9% and 6.5% post-tax real, respectively. SVT is known to be strong on totex outperformance while we believe UU can achieve financing outperformance. But we highlight that we think PNN can achieve both. These 5-year averages compare reasonably against those achieved by PNN/SVT/UU of around 7.5%/8.0%/8.0% average from FY02 to FY13.
• M&A of large-cap whole water companies remain possible and ongoing stake sales of regulated gas distribution assets in the UK by SSE and NG offer evidence of continued interest in UK regulated utilities/infrastructure. At 40% premium-to-RAB, capital returns are roughly 13%/18%29% for PNN SVT/UU. But transactions at individual business assets/segments are more likely in our view.
• Ofwat's regulation - The regulator is changing the UK Water landscape with every new proposal, though the water stocks appear to have become a lot more resilient to price volatility on days when Ofwat makes its announcements. We discuss the four changes that have gained perhaps the most traction and attention.

11:46 am
BE

And ............

BE

Pennon (950p price target from 925p, OP) - We believe PNN offers a one-stop shop for investors seeking exposure to various long-term themes, including water/waste, safety amidst Brexit, macro recovery (relative to SVT/UU), income-play, earnings growth and UK Water M&A. Please see page 25 for a summary of PNN estimate changes.

Pennon Group PLC (PNN:LSE): Last: 876.00, down 17.5 (-1.96%), High: 895.50, Low: 874.00, Volume: 362.72k
11:46 am
BE

But ...........

BE

SVT (2300p price target), UU (1000p price target) - We believe M&A potential is the only true relative attraction for investors buying (or holding onto) SVT and UU at current trading levels. Both also offer safety and inflation protection amidst Brexit, but so does Pennon, plus more. We think both SVT and UU have healthy financials and are led by respectable management, but with implied total returns of-5% (SVT) and +4% (UU), versus PNN's +10% and SX6P's +18%, we see Underperform as appropriate.

PM

Ambient Paradigm

11:52 am
BE

Oh, great. One of them.

PM

In computing, ambient intelligence (AmI) refers to electronic environments that are sensitive and responsive to the presence of people. Ambient intelligence is a vision on the future of consumer electronics, telecommunications and computing that was originally developed in the late 1990s for the time frame 2010–2020. In an ambient intelligence world, devices work in concert to support people in carrying out their everyday life activities, tasks and rituals in an easy, natural way using information and intelligence that is hidden in the network connecting these devices (see Internet of Things). As these devices grow smaller, more connected and more integrated into our environment, the technology disappears into our surroundings until only the user interface remains perceivable by users.

PM

That's wikipedia

11:53 am
PM

Oh, shoot are we allowed to use WIkipedia now?

PM

I'll just give you UBS and get out of the way

PM

Little optionality priced into the stock
Investors don't seem to have much faith in Apple's future. Our residual income model
finds that only 11% of the market cap is attributable to profits beyond three years.
Alternatively, we calculate that the current price reflects slight annual declines in the
size of the installed base and the dollars per customer spent with Apple. If there is little
beyond the iPhone, this cautious view should prove correct. However, we believe Apple
is preparing for the next era of personal technology—the Ambient Paradigm.
Unobtrusive, ubiquitous connectivity
Forecasting the company's future based on today's products is difficult. Mac sales in
2001 or iPod units in 2007 didn't have much to say about where the puck was going.
We think of Apple's evolution in paradigms. The Computer Paradigm (Mac) yielded to
the current Mobile Paradigm. An important clue was the iPod, a transition offering. We
consider the Apple Watch and AirPods similar transition products today on the way to
an integrated user experience based on multiple products seamlessly connected. We
call it the Ambient (present on all sides) Paradigm. It is Tim Cook's "iOS everywhere."

11:53 am
PM

Ambience may be the next scarcity
Ambience requires hardware, software, and orchestration. Although the iPhone
remains important in new uses such as AR, we expect the Watch, AirPods, and possibly
other wearables to evolve beyond current functionality and potentially impact hard-todisrupt
industries such as healthcare and education. Siri increasingly can play traffic
cop, invoking services enabled by Apple opening up APIs, to provide a seamless user
experience across devices whether the consumer is sitting, walking, shopping, or
driving. We suggest that this trusted, connected ecosystem could be the next scarcity.
Valuation: Buy with potential upside to long-term growth estimates
The current price appears to reflect gradual erosion in the installed base and the
roughly $350 in annual customer expenditure, which we think conservative based on
our product expectations and sensitivity analysis. Our price target is $127 or 14x our
F17E EPS. We believe Apple's discount to the market of 30% should narrow closer to
its five-year average of 20% as investors perceive life beyond F18.

Q: Will Apple be displaced like most other hardware vendors?
Investors are sensitive to the risk of disruption, especially when margins are as attractive as Apple's.
We think answering this question requires taking a longer view and recognizing that Apple evolves in
product paradigms. Success in the coming Ambient Paradigm could allow Apple to stay relevant.
more
Q: Will the iPhone 7 show growth?
Yes. Even if upgrade cycles lengthen in F17, the size of the installed base and the maturation of the
F15 iPhone class should be enough to drive mid-single-digit growth in iPhone units. Given current
retention rates, we expect a larger cycle in F18 as a differentiated model flushes out pent-up demand.
"Updated iPhone Demand Model Increases Confidence in at Least 5% Growth in F17" 8/3/2016
Q: Is Apple's gross margin sustainable?
Given our 5% iPhone unit growth estimate, we are forecasting a F17 gross margin of 39.4%, slightly
above F16's estimated 39% but below F15 due to the SE contribution. Apple faces potential margin
headwinds in F17/18 as the benefits from deferred revenue and lower warranty accruals wane and the
iPhone SE...

BE

The Bottom Line – GOOG is significantly ramping up its efforts in hardware with
its own phones, VR headset, and home automation products. While the products
are mostly me too, in theory Google’s unique AI and voice recognition capabilities
could be its key differentiator. GOOG’s past attempts at hardware (Nexus,
Chromebooks, Glass, Nest, etc...) have not amounted to much and given their
track record, we are not going to give them the benefit of the doubt on any
hardware efforts until we see otherwise.
Unsurprisingly, the real innovation is on the software side with GOOG clearly
trying to incorporate its new AI powered Google Assistant as a core component of
the Google and Android ecosystems. The Pixel phone and Google Home are the
first products built around the Assistant but others are likely on the way. AMZN’s
Echo has a large lead but the combination of the Google Assistant, search and
maps, and the ability to seamlessly move the conversation across the home,
mobile and desktop could be enough for GOOG to catch up. Though, that
functionality will need to be available on more Android phones than GOOG’s own
Pixel for that to be the case.
The headset for Google’s Daydream VR platform is certainly interesting, and
giving it away with Pixel pre-orders is a good start but like all the other VR
platforms out this year, the content will be key and the addition of a motion-
tracking controller should help. Unfortunately we have yet to see any killer VR
apps that will significantly drive adoption in the near-term.
The bottom line is the VR and AI capabilities shown are interesting but we don’t
see much hardware here that’s particularly innovative versus what’s currently in
the market. We think this is particularly disappointing given GOOG’s focus on
R&D, virtually unlimited resources and unique capabilities. Amazon is surprisingly
the current leader in home automation, yet it is still very early. Google will
immediately vault to a strong #2, however a strong reaction from Apple is virtually
assured. The bottom line is that while these new initiatives will attract a lot of
attention, the reality is the advertising CAGR over the next few years is the key
driver for the stock.

BE

All of which, I guess, justifies the decision to split Google into "advertising business that matters to investors" and "slew of other stuff that gets written about breathlessly on Techcrunch."
